titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Marianne Craig Moore (1887-1972) was an American poet. She graduated from Bryn Mawr College in 1909 as a biology major and then studied commercial subjects and taught them at the U.S. Indian School in Carlisle, Pennsylvania. Her first published work appeared in 1915 in the Egoist and in Harriet Monroe's Poetry magazine. After 1919, living in Brooklyn, New York, with her mother, Moore devoted herself to writing, contributing poetry and criticism to many journals in the United States and England. In 1921 her first book, Poems, was published in London by Hilda Doolittle and Winifred Ellerman (Bryher). In 1925, already well known as one of the leading new poets, she became acting editor of The Dial, an influential American journal of literature and arts, and she remained with The Dial until it was discontinued in 1929. Moore's Collected Poems appeared in 1951. A disciplined craftsman, Moore won the admiration of fellow poets throughout her long career. The poet and critic T.S. Eliot called her one of the few producers of durable poetry in her time.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers and ephemera of Marianne Moore. Materials include: a vertical file of newspaper clippings and magazine extracts on poets, writers, artists, politicians, and sports figures along with a variety of other topics; inscribed presentation copies of poems, speeches, art exhibition catalogues, and plays; clippings of reviews and articles about Moore; greeting cards; an extensive collection of (unsent) postcards; awards and honors; calendars; audio recordings of readings by Moore and others; corrected proofs of a collection of poems; scrapbooks; announcements and programs for Moore's poetry readings; passports of Moore and her mother, Mary Warner Moore; and obituaries of Moore and notices of readings done after her death. The collection also includes a small number of letters from Marianne Moore to Rev. Philip Magee, Marilouise Dormus, and Eleanor Glenn Wallis. Wallis was a poet, and Moore's letters to her, written between 1937 and 1959, discuss her poems, some writings of Wallis's son, and other literary and poetic subjects.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Bryn Mawr College: Marianne Moore papers; University of Rochester, Special Collections: Marianne Moore: Letters to Hildegarde Watson (1933-1964).
